title: Diploma in Floristry
headline: Learn how to become a florist and create a wide variety of flower arrangements with this free online diploma course.
description: This diploma course teaches you the essential skills required to become a successful florist. We offer a wealth of information, from flower and plant varieties to floral arrangements. If you ever considered turning your passion for flowers into a budding career, this diploma course also teaches you everything you need to know to run your own speciality flower shop. This course suits anyone with an eye for beauty and a love of flowers.
courseDescription:
This diploma course equips you with the skills and knowledge necessary to become a successful florist. We cover the basics of floristry and explain how to find and successfully apply for a job in the floristry industry. We explain how to run a flower shop, from purchasing essential equipment for arrangements to marketing your floristry skills on social media. We examine the anatomy of plants and flowers and explore different colour associations and usages. The course lays out the dangers and treatment of ethylene as we show you how to process, store and maintain plants. 

We then study specific species of popular flowers, foliage, greens and fillers to use in flower arrangements. There are many floral design styles, both western and eastern, and we take you through the elements and principles of each, including the popular Japanese ‘Ikebana’ technique. The course provides step-by-step instructions in creating specific types of floral arrangements, starting by identifying the role of vases and available flowers. We test your creative skills when we cover container and vase arrangements, hand-tied bouquets, boutonnière, basket gardens and fruit baskets. The course concludes with an in-depth study of the floral business, industry etiquette and flower arrangements specifically for weddings and funerals. 

This diploma course suits anyone who dreams of turning their passion for flowers and floristry into a career. We teach you everything you need to know to turn natural beauty into art and that art into a business.

Start Course Now

• Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Recall the basics of floristry.
    • Outline the history of floristry briefly.
    • Discuss the various ages of floristry and how it has evolved.
    • Describe modern floristry and the science it has become over the years.
    • Outline the requirements that are ideal for a career in floristry.
    • Summarise the responsibilities of a florist.

  • Floristry

  • Floristry includes everything that has to do with flowers, its care, handling, production, trading and other commercial activities involving flowers. It also includes such activities as sale and purchase of flowers and plants, the design of floral arrangements or flower arranging, their display and delivery.

    Florists who are wholesalers deal in bulk flower trading. This includes selling floristry related supplies to retail florists who, in turn, create arrangements, provide related services and sell to consumers directly.

    Most of the raw materials that are supplied to the floristry industry come from the producers of the cut flower. Florist eShops and bricks and mortar florists are the main dealers in cut flowers, though supermarkets and fuel stations also carry cut flowers and bouquets.

  • A Brief History

  • Traces, images and descriptions of flower decoration are found throughout history. We can see on tombs, and in reliefs from Egypt, Mesopotamia, Greece and ancient Rome, how different principles of design prevailed in the East and West down the ages. 

    The dead were honoured with Wreaths, Garlands and Festoons, yet the style used today for garlands, festoons and wreaths has not varied greatly in comparison to the ancient techniques. The arranging of flowers is an ancient form of artistic endeavour dating way back to ancient Egypt. 

    Throughout our world history, people have always coveted the natural beauty of fresh flowers. Just like it is today, floral arrangements brought colour and nature to everyday scenarios and also to special events. Although floral arrangement styles have clearly varied in history and across continents, they all had purpose and meaning embedded in it.

    From the earliest times, it was the gardener who made all the decorations personally, assisted by an apprentice. 

    Flower decorating ‘just’ had to be beautiful as its purpose and the gardeners made bunches with what was presently available during the seasons. So it remained for centuries until the dedicated art of arrangement and floristry emerged. The story of floristry is closely linked to the evolution of garden design, to general developments in taste and culture, and most relevantly with the decorative function of flowers in the home throughout history.

  • Responsibilities as a Florist

  • Being a florist is not a cakewalk. You have to be constantly on your feet to be good at your job. There is always something to do or take care of. The main responsibilities of a florist include:
    • When a shipment arrives, the unpacking of new stock.
    • Conditioning and maintaining the condition of plants and flowers.
    • Watering the plants.
    • Fixing the price of the stock.
    • Attending to walk-in customers, and those contacting via phone or e-mail. 
    • Taking down orders and details accurately. 
    • Maintaining a clean and attractive shop.
    • Managing the cash flow and daily accounts.
    • Creating floral arrangements for display and to sell at the shop.
    • Advising your customers about plant and flower aftercare.

  • Lesson Summary

    •  Floristry includes everything that has to do with flowers, its care, handling, production, trading and other commercial activities involving flowers. It also includes such activities as sale and purchase of flowers and plants, the design of floral arrangements or flower arranging, their display and delivery. 
    • Creating flower arrangements, bouquets, wreaths and other such products using flowers, foliage and other organic material is called floral arts or floral design. It also includes creating arrangements in vases, bowls, trays, and other such holders using herbs, grasses, leaves and twigs, etc. along with flowers. 
    • There is no hard and fast or definitive and prescriptive set of rules for floristry. 
    • With an ever-unfolding interest in the natural world and in flowers, the floral industry continues to expand. The increase in educational institutes offering education and training in floristry and floral design has also grown to include many universities and also certified design schools worldwide.
    • The honour of the most expensive flower or plant ever goes to the black hyacinth. Three bulbs of this plant went for £150,000 in 1997. 
    • First and foremost, one must have a keen interest in flowers. If you do have that keenness, then nothing you encounter in your role as a florist will make you feel that it is a job or a drudge. 
    • The main responsibilities of a florist include: unpacking of new stock, conditioning and maintaining the condition of plants and flowers, watering the plants, fixing the price of the stock, attending to walk-in customers, and those contacting via phone or e-mail, taking down orders and details accurately, maintaining a clean and attractive shop, managing the cash flow and daily accounts, creating floral arrangements for display and to sell at the shop and advising your customers about plant and flower aftercare.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Define the possibilities and challenges you can expect in the floristry industry.
    • Identify the business models available from which florists can choose.
    • Outline the job responsibilities, requirements and hours of florists.
    • Describe how to start and advance a career in floristry.
    • Describe how to find or create job opportunities.
    • Describe how to prepare, conduct and followup during the interview process.

  • Floristry as a Career

    • Introduction
    • Long Hours

      Enter your text here..
    • Floristry as a career can be quite hard, but there are also some incredible rewards. Remember to just keep on trying, help others out, go above and beyond, be creative and personable, push your boundaries, be resourceful and overall simply enjoy yourself! You are up close with nature every single day, so do take time to remember and cherish this.

      On the whole, florists work out of a retail store in which they design, prepare and subsequently sell the creations direct to customers. Taking orders over the telephone or via email and sending out flowers for delivery is also a common part of the work.

      Many florists do choose to work from a stall where they can also tempt and take advantage of passing customers. Frequently florists will travel to special events like marriages, funerals, christenings and corporate events to create arrangements and displays.

      Florists can work for retail outlets or in their own businesses. The potential challenges, if you choose this career, will include much time spent at work in cool temperatures and very long hours on the popular yearly celebrations and holidays.

Remember to just keep on trying, help others out, go above and beyond, be creative and personable, push your boundaries, be resourceful and overall simply enjoy yourself! You are up close with nature every single day, so do take time to remember and cherish this.

      On the whole, florists work out of a retail store in which they design, prepare and subsequently sell the creations direct to customers. Taking orders over the telephone or via email and sending out flowers for delivery is also a common part of the work.

      Many florists do choose to work from a stall where they can also tempt and take advantage of passing customers. Frequently florists will travel to special events like marriages, funerals, christenings and corporate events to create arrangements and displays.

      Florists can work for retail outlets or in their own businesses. The potential challenges, if you choose this career, will include much time spent at work in cool temperatures and very long hours on the popular yearly celebrations and holidays.
    • Working fairly long hours means usually getting started very early in the morning to buy stocks of fresh flowers from wholesale suppliers or central markets.

      As a retail business, you would workshop hours. Florists are generally open to the general public from 8 am – 6 pm, including Saturdays and possibly Sundays, and work extra hours to make sure that orders are completed on time – especially at busy times such as Christmas and Valentine’s Day.

      You could work at a shop or an outside stall. Most of your time would be spent on your feet, either putting together flower arrangements on a bench in the workroom or ‘out front’ dealing with customers. There may be requirements to travel to make deliveries to customers or to collect from nurseries and other suppliers.

      A career in floristry could be physically demanding due to the early starts and much time spent on one’s feet; there might also be occasional heavy lifting involved such as shifting pots and plants, urns or other display items which can be heavy.
      Working fairly long hours means usually getting started very early in the morning in order to buy stocks of fresh flowers from wholesale suppliers or central markets.

      As a retail business, you would workshop hours. Florists are generally open to the general public from 8 am – 6 pm, including Saturdays and possibly Sundays, and work extra hours to make sure that orders are completed on time – especially at busy times such as Christmas and Valentine’s Day.

      You could work at a shop or at an outside stall. Most of your time would be spent on your feet, either putting together flower arrangements on a bench in the workroom or ‘out front’ dealing with customers. There may be requirements to travel to make deliveries to customers or to collect from nurseries and other suppliers.

      A career in floristry could be physically demanding due to the early starts and much time spent on one’s feet; there might also be occasional heavy lifting involved such as shifting pots and plants, urns or other display items which can be heavy.
    • As in all retail work, interacting with the customers is one of the more rewarding but also more exacting facets of the work. Training is vital. Therefore after doing plenty of your research, undertake some voluntary work at a local florist if possible.

      This simplest method of gaining experience is getting your hands dirty and observing the techniques of senior florists. This will prove to be an excellent foundational experience, which undoubtedly will stand you in good stead for the future.

      College is, of course, also a great way to study and learn, but as floristry is a highly practical and labour intensive activity, being in the thick of things is the best way to get exposure and confirm if this is the right career choice for you.

      The most common way to become a florist is in fact the hands-on route; finding assistant work with a shop or a business and training on the job, while simultaneously completing a part-time work-based qualification course.

      Working fairly long hours means usually getting started very early in the morning in order to buy stocks of fresh flowers from wholesale suppliers or central markets.

      As a retail business, you would workshop hours. Florists are generally open to the general public from 8 am – 6 pm, including Saturdays and possibly Sundays, and work extra hours to make sure that orders are completed on time – especially at busy times such as Christmas and Valentine’s Day.

  • Getting Started

  • Once you have completed the course your main aim will either be to open your own business or to look for employment within the industry.

    If you do not have much prior experience of the industry and wish to open your own business, you will be well advised to work for a year or two at a floristry to gain experience and know the ropes before starting. Newbies often flounder when setting off without any knowledge.

  • What Florists Are Looking For

  • Before you start in earnest to look and apply for jobs, you need to know what the florists are looking for in people they wish to hire. There are some basic things they all look for and these include:
    • An interest in flowers, floral art and plants.
    • Have a degree of creativity and sense of aesthetics so you can create floral art and arrangements that are attractive and appealing.
    • Have a good sense of colour harmony and sense of proportion.
    • Marketing and social skills.
    • Pleasing personality and friendly, as this is a job where interaction with people is essential.
    • Understanding the customers, their needs and urgencies.
    • Should be able to work fast and efficiently under pressure.
    • Be a team player and integrate well with the team.
    • Should be self-confident and self-motivated with the ability to work independently.
    • Excellent communication skill to be able to deal with customers satisfactorily, attend to customers and take orders and instructions online as well as on the phone.

  • What Florists Are Looking For

  • Before you start in earnest to look and apply for jobs, you need to know what the florists are looking for in people they wish to hire. There are some basic things they all look for and these include:
    • An interest in flowers, floral art and plants.
    • Have a degree of creativity and sense of aesthetics so you can create floral art and arrangements that are attractive and appealing.
    • Have a good sense of colour harmony and sense of proportion.
    • Marketing and social skills.
    • Pleasing personality and friendly, as this is a job where interaction with people is essential.
    • Understanding the customers, their needs and urgencies.
    • Should be able to work fast and efficiently under pressure.
    • Be a team player and integrate well with the team.
    • Should be self-confident and self-motivated with the ability to work independently.
    • Excellent communication skill to be able to deal with customers satisfactorily, attend to customers and take orders and instructions online as well as on the phone.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Floristry as a career can be quite hard, but there are also some incredible rewards. Remember to just keep on trying, help others out, go above and beyond, be creative and personable, push your boundaries, be resourceful and overall simply enjoy yourself!
    • Florists are generally open to the general public from 8am – 6pm, including Saturdays and possibly Sundays, and work extra hours to make sure that orders are completed on time – especially at busy times such as Christmas and Valentine’s Day.
    • A career in floristry could be physically demanding due to the early starts and much time spent on one’s feet; there might also be occasional heavy lifting involved such as shifting pots and plants, urns or other display items which can be heavy.
    • Training is vital. Therefore after doing plenty of your research, undertake some voluntary work at a local florist if possible. The well-worn entry into this career is the hands-on route, with an established florist who trains you on the job. To become a successful florist, your creations need to be innovative, attractive and appealing.
    • Aimed at young people, typically aged between 16 and 24 years, apprenticeships enable you to gain critical work experience in the floristry industry while also studying for a qualification which is recognised nationally.
    • The opportunities for advancement of one’s career in the retail floral industry are quite often limited, so competition can be stiff, which will bring out the best in you.
    • On the whole, floristry is a job or a career that one enters for the love of it, not with the goal of becoming a millionaire. For example, a junior florist in London may expect to earn around £15,000, and that is after training and with experience.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the various business models applicable to floristry.
    • Recognise the different types of services provided by florists, which include full service, speciality service, limited service and flower sellers.
    • Explain how to use creativity and innovation to make your business a success.
    • Identify the secrets of handling commercial accounts and targeting individuals successfully.
    • Compare the differences between handling commercial accounts and individuals. 
    • Explain how to use technology to improve business.

  • Floristry as a Career

  • Floristry can be a fantastic career which may lead to opening your own business, or outlet. However, there are choices to make or options to explore before you decide what you may want to do with your career or business in floristry. To make the right choice, you need to know the areas into which you can diversify as a florist.

    When you begin your career as a florist, you will probably be working for someone else at the start. Once you have worked a few years in the industry and earned your certifications, or have gained enough experience, you might want to either continue with your job or start your own business. If you continue with your job, you will not have to worry about much, but if you wish to start your own business you will need to do some serious thinking.

  • Types of Services Provided

  • The range of services that a floristry provides will depend entirely upon the business model you choose for your business. Here we assume, for sake of clarity, that you are planning on a self-employed business, which is the most common floristry business model in the UK. 

    Since you are the business, you have greater freedom in choosing the services you wish to provide to your customers. You have the choice whether to specialise in one facet of the floristry industry, such as weddings – or to proffer a broader palette of floristry services. No florist will ever ignore marriages, which are a multi-billion pound sector. People like to splurge on marriages and, most of the time, spend a lot on flowers and floral decorations, providing many opportunities for a lucrative and creative career. 

    Based on the types of services you provide, you can choose to be any of the following:
    • Professional Full Service
    • Speciality
    • Limited Service
    • Flower Trading

  • Handling Commercial Accounts

  • If you wish to concentrate on commercial, institutional and other such organisations for your services, you need to be very professional in your approach. When trying to win over commercial contracts consider that these are high volume clients and can be very good references for your future success. So if you have to settle for less profit, keep this in mind.

  • Lesson Summary

    • When you begin your career as a florist, you will probably be working for someone else in the beginning. Once you have worked a few years in the industry and earned your certifications, or have gained enough experience, you might want to either continue with your job or start your own business. 
    • The most common business model for florists is as a self-employed business. These florists are mainly small business types working locally or taking wire orders. This model gives you the greatest freedom regarding the services you wish to provide your customers. 
    • The next model is that of a small business. These florists employ between 1–4 employees. 
    • Then there is the order service florist. They typically take orders online and on the phone and pass them on to member florists. These are businesses which network with other smaller florists all over the country, and sometimes internationally, to provide floristry services to their clients. 
    • Interflora is the largest internet-based flower delivery service in the UK. It has a network of more than 1800 florists. Its main business is online or phone orders. 
    • The Internet has been a significant paradigm shift for traditional florists and may have spelt a decline in the traditional, independently owned flower shops.

    • The Internet has been a significant paradigm shift for traditional florists and may have spelt a decline in the traditional, independently owned flower shops.

  • Lesson Summary

    • When you begin your career as a florist, you will probably be working for someone else in the beginning. Once you have worked a few years in the industry and earned your certifications, or have gained enough experience, you might want to either continue with your job or start your own business. 
    • The most common business model for florists is as a self-employed business. These florists are mainly small business types working locally or taking wire orders. This model gives you the greatest freedom regarding the services you wish to provide your customers.

    • The Internet has been a significant paradigm shift for traditional florists and may have spelt a decline in the traditional, independently owned flower shops.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Outline what to consider before you start to set up a flower shop.
    • Create a business and financial plan.
    • Decide whether you want to buy an existing business or to start a new one.
    • Identify the taxes, permits, licences, insurance, supplies and equipment required.
    • Describe the types of wholesalers and suppliers available.
    • Describe the types of orders and deliveries you want to provide.

  • Before You Start

  • We now come to the most important part of this course, which is finally getting you started in the business of Floristry and establishing your own business. It is a daunting task to take the first step toward a huge commitment, and if you are doing it, we assume you have weighed the pros and cons of all that running a business entails. If you haven’t, then now is the time before you invest any more of your time, effort or money into the job. 

    This is called self-inventory and is the most crucial part of the process. See if you have the following qualities that are requisites of a successful entrepreneur.
    • Motivation
    • Confidence
    • Patience
    • Tenacity
    • Resilience
  • Evaluate yourself on these criteria to score yourself. If you feel that the score is satisfactory, then go ahead and start
    your own business, if not, you are better off looking for employment in a floristry rather than starting one yourself.

  • Choosing a Location and Rental Costs

  • Floristry is a highly visual business and, to attract customers, you will have to be conveniently located.

    The location for a florist shop is extremely important. The shop needs to be in a place where there is high footfall and people can drop in casually as they walk by. Normally, this would mean having a business in a busy market, busy streets or a mall. This means having a shop in an expensive part of town that could cost you a lot in lease and rent.

    If you would rather build up your business before committing too much of your cost allocation to the premises, a good way to start is by having a flower kiosk on a busy street corner or outside the entrance of a mall or office building or a station, etc. These kiosks are not too expensive to lease and can help you build up your resources before taking on the responsibility of running a full-fledged shop.

    Your rentals costs will depend upon the location of your business. If you choose to open a full-service floristry, you will need to have a business in a visible part of the market where you can expect a lot of customers.

    Such locations are not cheap and you could be spending a major portion of your turnover on your rental and lease.

    A good option is to start as a service provider and start from home where your rental costs are minimal.

  • Buying an Established Shop

  • Buying an established floristry will give you a running start to your business; you inherit the goodwill and the customers of the existing business.

    But this can be expensive, as whoever built up the business and is selling it, may want more for the established reputation and clientele.

    You also inherit the employees and the establishment including the lease agreement, etc. But you should not just pitch in your money as soon as you hear about a business on sale.

    Buying a business is much like buying anything else, you have to give it careful consideration and also to research the business thoroughly before making an offer.

  • Supplies and Equipment

  • You will need a steady supply of consumables and flowers for your business. You will also need equipment, tools and other hardware. Create a list of the things that you think you will need and then run it by someone who is already in the business for their comments, inclusions and exclusions. 

    Remember, it is best to start small and keep the costs to a minimum. There is always scope to buy more and better equipment as your business prospers. Don’t invest too much on expensive equipment that is not essential for the business in the initial stages. If you can do away with fancy equipment and make do with something less expensive, by all means, do it. The same applies to supplies and stock.

    You do not need to buy a lot of stuff all at once, you can buy in smaller lots and buy more as and when you need. The wholesaler is not going away and you can order more. This is especially true of cut flowers. You may be tempted to buy more, but remember they are highly perishable and you may actually see your profits rotting away if you are not careful.

    That said, here is what you need by way of supplies and equipment:

  • Store Layout and Maintenance

  • The layout of your shop is an important aspect of your business.

    How you have placed all the things in your shop and how your products are displayed, have an impact on the customers who walk into your shop.

    If there is too much crammed in a small space, it is visually confusing and the customer may miss seeing all that you have to offer.

    On the other hand, if there is too little on display, the customer may be disappointed in the selection and walk out.

    The layout of your shop determines the shopping experience for your customers and you should aim at making it comfortable, easy and pleasant for your customers.

    Your shop should be inviting and not forbidding. Much will depend upon the shape and size of your shop, but whatever the shape and size, it can still be made pretty and inviting.

  • Store Layout and Maintenance

  • The layout of your shop is an important aspect of your business.

    How you have placed all the things in your shop and how your products are displayed, have an impact on the customers who walk into your shop.

    If there is too much crammed in a small space, it is visually confusing and the customer may miss seeing all that you have to offer.

    On the other hand, if there is too little on display, the customer may be disappointed in the selection and walk out.

    The layout of your shop determines the shopping experience for your customers and you should aim at making it comfortable, easy and pleasant for your customers.

    Your shop should be inviting and not forbidding. Much will depend upon the shape and size of your shop, but whatever the shape and size, it can still be made pretty and inviting.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Florsitry is a tough business, especially if you have to compete with impossible competitors like the supermarket and their flower sections that sell flowers at cut rates when compared to the florists.
    • One thing you have to do is create a business plan, which needs to have the following: executive summary, company description, market analysis organisation & management, product & service, sales & marketing, funding request & financial projections and appendix.
    • Your next step is budgeting, to secure finance or to self finance your business, you will need to determine the amount of money you will require for your business. 
    • You need to settle the company ownership, either a sole proprietorship or a partnership model. Most florists are self-employed businesses. 
    • Floristry is a highly visual business and, to attract customers, you will have to be conveniently located.
    • Most businesses have to pay a certain amount of fees and permit charges to run their business. Some of the fees you can expect include registration fees, professional fees, legal advice feea, a fee for registering your business, utilities, domain registration fee, licences & permits and insurance. 
    • Eventually, a business is dependent upon its customers’ purchasing power and willingness to pay. So, keep this in mind when setting your prices.
    • One thing that you will encounter in the course of your work is deliveries. The services provided include: freight deliveries(bulk or very large deliveries), special deliveries(odd things, like documents, bouquets, flowers), routed deliveries(scheduled deliveries) and courier service(same day, fast and reliable).

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Summarise the concept of marketing.
    • Explain how to create and implement a marketing plan.
    • Describe how online marketing works and how it can benefit you.
    • Outline how to promote yourself using social media.
    • Discuss email advertising and traditional advertising methods.
    • Explain how to deal with customers.

  • Business Survival

  • To survive, a business requires customers. Likewise, customers require businesses to fulfil their needs. But to get the two together is the main problem. How does a business get customers and how do customers find a business which can fulfil their needs. The intermediary between the two is the field of marketing. No business can ignore marketing and expect to succeed.

    • Once your plan is in place and written down and you have allocated your budget, you need to start implementing your marketing strategy and find customers.

      Know Your Customer
      The first thing that you need to do is to identify your customers, discover their tastes and needs. You may do this by one to one interaction with the clients as they drop in or you can go a step further and conduct research. You don’t need to hire a research company or spend too much money on it. You can create a questionnaire and hand it over to people you meet or who drop into your shop. This will give you a fair idea of your customers.

      If you are targeting institutional or other specialized niches, you need to search through the local directories and find out which organizations or institutes, hotels, restaurants, hospitals etc. you can tap for your business.

      Take Care of Your Customer
      Once you have a few customers, you need to take care of them and give them your best service. It is common knowledge that gaining a new customer is far more expensive than retaining an old one. So do not neglect old customers for the sake of a new one. If you are on very friendly terms with a customer give them something extra and seek out their feedback and suggestion for improvement of your services.
      Enter your text here..

      Customer Name
    • Promote and Advertise
      This is perhaps the most important aspect of your marketing strategy. This helps to create awareness of your presence, not just in the neighbourhood but also in other markets. There are many tools for advertising and promotion available to florists. The cheapest ones are signage and banners, posters, stickers, etc. that you can put up on your own shop front, sidewalk and other public places. Your vehicle can also act as a mobile signboard. Just put some banners or stickers on your vehicle for a lot of free publicity. Have a uniform for your business, it is a good way of advertising your business.

      Invest in Public Relations
      If you wish to get a lot of free publicity for yourself, invest in PR. Local journalists, bloggers, reviewers and other
      such individuals can provide you with a valuable source of free publicity through their columns, blogs and reviews. You have to have a very good rapport or an interesting story before you can get them interested in your business. So make sure that you do have an interesting story to pass on or an innovative product, perhaps a new exotic plant that no other competitor has or a service that no one else is offering. Even if they do not write about you in the beginning, keep working on building your relations as eventually, it will work out.
      Enter your text here..
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Holding and Sponsoring Events
      Another way to attract attention and create a market for your business is by getting involved with the community.
      Sponsor charities, participate by offering to become a collection point for contribution to a charity. Hold events where you may provide a free class on identifying the various flowers, or by teaching people the basics of flower arranging, etc.

      Holding competitions for children in flower arranging is another way to engage the community. It will also help your PR as the local media is likely to be interested in such events and will carry a news item or a press release for you.

      The Power of Networking
      Networking is a great way to get word of mouth publicity and referrals. Aligning yourself with services that require flowers and flower arrangements such as funeral homes, party planners, wedding planners, caterers, etc. would help your business grow.

There are many tools for advertising and promotion available to florists. The cheapest ones are signage and banners, posters, stickers, etc. that you can put up on your own shop front, sidewalk and other public places. Your vehicle can also act as a mobile signboard. Just put some banners or stickers on your vehicle for a lot of free publicity. Have a uniform for your business, it is a good way of advertising your business.

      Invest in Public Relations
      If you wish to get a lot of free publicity for yourself, invest in PR. Local journalists, bloggers, reviewers and other
      such individuals can provide you with a valuable source of free publicity through their columns, blogs and reviews. You have to have a very good rapport or an interesting story before you can get them interested in your business. So make sure that you do have an interesting story to pass on or an innovative product, perhaps a new exotic plant that no other competitor has or a service that no one else is offering. Even if they do not write about you in the beginning, keep working on building your relations as eventually, it will work out.

    • Networking
      Holding and Sponsoring Events
      Another way to attract attention and create a market for your business is by getting involved with the community.
      Sponsor charities, participate by offering to become a collection point for contribution to a charity. Hold events where you may provide a free class on identifying the various flowers, or by teaching people the basics of flower arranging, etc.

      Holding competitions for children in flower arranging is another way to engage the community. It will also help your PR as the local media is likely to be interested in such events and will carry a news item or a press release for you.

      The Power of Networking
      Networking is a great way to get word of mouth publicity and referrals. Aligning yourself with services that require flowers and flower arrangements such as funeral homes, party planners, wedding planners, caterers, etc. would help your business grow.

  • Online Advertising

  • If you are looking for a cheap way to advertise your business, online advertisement is a good way to go. There are many benefits of online marketing and these include:
    • Cost-effective
    • Great return on investment
    • Easy to set up
    • Greater coverage
    • Targeted advertising aimed at specific demographic profiles based upon your preferences for clientele
    • Area-specific advertising
    • Can control how long the campaign runs
    • Control the budget for online advertising and make the best of your investment by targeting it at the audience that is most likely to convert.
    • Cheaper conversions than traditional marketing.
  • Online advertising can be done as pop-ups, pay per click ads, banners and side panels on specific web pages. Google AdSense is a good place to look for online advertising. Facebook also offers online advertisements.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Marketing is creating awareness about your business, its services, and its products. It is based upon four principles called the four P’s (Product, Price, Place and Promotion). Whatever strategy you use, the result is always to find the customers for your product.
    • The first step to great marketing is creating a marketing plan. The plan should detail: target market, uniqueness of your business, budget, pricing, market trends & conditions and marketing goals & research.
    • Once your plan is in place you need to start implementing your marketing strategy and find customers. Keep in mind that you will need to know your customers, take care of your customers, promote & advertise, invest in public relations, hold & sponsor events and network.
    • Floristry, like any other business, needs to have an online presence. To create an online profile, you will need to have a website. Developing the website is just the start of online marketing.
    • Once your site is up and running you will have to create awareness for your website, get your website indexed for search results on a search engine, create a decent search page rank, get your business enlisted in a web directory, create hype for your business, engage in social media and online advertising.
    • The next task is to bring your website on to the first page of any search and then, eventually to the top ten, which is where all the online business is concentrated. To do so you have to engage in SEO – or Search Engine Optimisation. SEO is a field dedicated to optimiaing websites only to create a better search rank.
    • Any mention of your business on the internet will give you a cookie point with the search engine and it will improve your page rank. The more popular your business is, the better the page rank for your business.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain what ethylene treatment of flowers is and why it is essential to treat the flowers for ethylene.
    • Describe how to care for and handle potted plants.
    • Identify the signs of diseases, pests and other such troubles with plants and flowers. 
    • Describe the importance of flower colours, associations and symbolisms.
    • Identify the parts and systems of plants and flowers.
    • Identify plants that are good for health.

  • Introduction to Plants and Flowers

  • The lovely thing about working in floristry is that the flowers one works with are so beautiful and diverse. You can be accessing fantastic, enormous heavy tropical flowers, or small, soft, pretty, spring flowers. It is very sensory. Florists are dab-hands at creating magic with nature’s raw materials. The variety of flowers and plants that can be used by florists is mind-boggling. Which flowers you use depends upon your creativity and the demands of your customers.

    Most common, local and national flower varieties will be found at the local professional florist, but with an expanding global market, and advanced technology, more and more international varieties are becoming available year-round. 

    The most important raw material for floristry is flowers and plants. The flowers are mostly in the cut form and highly perishable if they are not cared for properly. The plants also need regular care and inspection to eliminate diseases and pests. This is all part of the florist’s job. We will discuss some of the following topics in detail in our next module, but it needs to be mentioned here what you have to do to keep your inventory from perishing and maximising your profit.

  • The Parts of a Plant

  • When most people look upon a plant, the last thing they normally think about is the anatomy. Instead, they marvel at the shape of the stem or the intricate designs that make up the leaves. 

    However, there is a lot more than colour and design when it comes to plants, and understanding the anatomy of a plant is important for their care and to ensure they thrive. Every plant is made up of four main parts, roots, stem, leaves and flowers, and each of these parts is made up of other parts, all with equal importance.

    However, there is a lot more than colour and design when it comes to plants, and understanding the anatomy of a plant is important for their care and to ensure they thrive. Every plant is made up of four main parts, roots, stem, leaves and flowers, and each of these parts is made up of other parts, all with equal importance.

  • Flower Colour

  • In the natural environment, the flower colours are repeated almost accidentally in clumps, or seen as individual floating patches in a backfield of green. However, the scope remains for intentional colour regimes, associating plants for colour is a vital component of the skill of a florist’s vision. Colour is the main feature of all floral arrangements. 

    A basic understanding of colour enables a florist to create beautiful arrangements. The colour wheel, saturation, tone, harmony and contrast, and their distribution are useful and practical in every sphere of creative life, including floristry.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Colour is the most important weapon in the toolbox, as is their juxtaposition in the floral arrangers’ palette. Colour can evoke and suggest many different moods. We adjust our choices of colour to our environments, and it’s a complex art to use colour to alter the sense of space, to suggest coolness or warmth, and to evoke ambience, etc.

  • Ethylene Treatment

  • Ethylene is a gas that is produced naturally by plants and some synthetic materials. Though it is not harmful to humans, it can wreak havoc in harvested plants, vegetables and flowers. 

    Even in small concentrations, it can affect harvest quality by premature ripening, wilting, browning and yellowing of plants and flowers. It is a by-product of all plants and any dead or rotting plant emits it. 

    Ethylene is difficult to detect. But there are some plants that are good indicators of ethylene even in very low concentrates. Tomato and cuphea are two plants that can be used as indicator plants. Another way of detecting it is by taking air samples and getting them tested. This is more reliable but expensive and time-consuming. But if you suspect ethylene in your floristry, do get the air tested.
  • Florists need to eliminate it at all stages from procurement to selling, to prevent their profits from wilting away. Effects of ethylene on plants and cut flowers can be drastic even at very low levels.
  • Here is what is does:
    • Makes leaves and buds fall off
    • Makes leaves go yellow
    • Causes a loss of colour in flowers
    • Makes petals fall off
    • Makes blooming of buds irregular
    • Can cause plants and flowers to die early

  • Lesson Summary

    • The most important raw material for floristry is flowers and plants. The flowers are mostly in the cut form and highly perishable if they are not cared for properly. The plants also need regular care and inspection to eliminate diseases and pests. This is all part of the florist’s job.
    • Scientifically, a flower is the reproductive parts of any plant in the Magnoliophyta division of the classification. Commonly, the population generally refers to these organisms as ‘flowers.’
    • Starting from the stem of the flower, which is the main support for the flower, and moving up to the part that is furthest away from the stem. The parts of the flower include the sepal, petal, stigma, style, ovary, ovule, anther, filament, pistil and stamen.
    • When sexual reproduction occurs in flowering plants, the process is known as pollination. During the process, the male gametes are transferred to the female ovules in a variety of means. When pollination occurs, the ovules are fertilised, and they turn into seeds.
    • Ethylene is a gas that is produced naturally by plants and some synthetic materials. Even in small concentrations, it can affect harvest quality by premature ripening, wilting, browning and yellowing of plants and flowers.
    • Ethylene is difficult to detect. The best treatment for ethylene is to find and eliminate the source. One way of detecting it is by taking air samples and getting them tested. This is more reliable but expensive and time-consuming.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss processing and maintaining cut flowers.
    • Identify products that help to maintain cut flowers.
    • Describe how to maintain cleanliness while processing flowers.
    • Discuss preparing the flowers for storage.
    • Explain how to process and pot plants.
    • List ways to keep the plants healthy.

  • Requirements of a Plant

  • All plants require food, water and sunlight for survival, but different species naturally require different amounts of each. This is as true for houseplants as it is for plants in a nursery or a garden. For example, ficus trees thrive with indirect light and moist soil generally, whereas cacti require dry soil and bright light. 

    It is not really so difficult to make houseplants happy, but attention needs to be paid to their basic needs, but deal with any pest problems immediately. Healthy plants will defend themselves better by warding off disease and pests far more easily than a weak plant.

  • Processing Cut Flowers

  • If you own or work at a florist shop, or work with cut flowers, then do you have a set of procedures for processing flowers?

    If so, do you keep to those procedures? Most florists will understand what they should be doing, but so often, they will let other demands on their time interfere with what should be done. Shortcuts are taken, simply because care and handling procedures are not enshrined as a top priority. At times, it is understandable.

  • Maintaining Cut Flowers

  • In a bid to offer customers fresh flowers that are as radiant as the moment that they were picked, florists utilise an array of keep-fresh techniques. Naturally, the exact application of such techniques slightly varies between florists; nearly all florists will be using a variety of these basic practices.

    Fresh, clean water is the elixir for cut flowers. Just as one keeps flowers submerged in water in a vase in a house, then florists must store their stems soaking in water, which ensures the flowers will stand a test of time. Ensure each flower receptacle contains water, and that the water is fresh.

Just as one keeps flowers submerged in water in a vase in a house, then florists must store their stems soaking in water, which ensures the flowers will stand a test of time. Ensure each flower receptacle contains water, and that the water is fresh.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Requirements of a plant: Indoor houseplants require regular fertilising to maintain their healthy growth, a good all-round fertiliser may be added straight into a watering can, a balanced formula contains a 6-12-6 fertiliser, vitamins and humic and amino acids and generally, most houseplants should be fertilised from January through September, and then allowed their ‘rest’ period for a few months. 
    • When processing cut flowers florists should remember to keep it clean, move flower immediately to a cooler, remove foliage, re-cut the stems, place flowers into solution and indicate the flowers for rotation. 
    • The steps in processing and plotting plants includes choosing the pot, choosing the potting mix, preparing the pots and potting the plant.
    • High temperatures, inadequate light, and improper watering are the most common reasons for failure when caring for flowering plants.
    • Bamboo is the fastest-growing woody plant in the world; it can grow 12 inches in a single day.
    • 5 Ways to Keep Houseplants Healthy: Inspect plants regularly, avoid putting plants in hot zones, provide ample light, air conditions may be very dry in winter because of the heated air and always plant in sterile soil. This will reduce any problem of fungus gnats and different soil-borne diseases.
    • Fresh, clean water is the elixir for cut flowers. Ensure each flower receptacle contains water, and that the water is fresh. While nothing will keep flowers fresh for so long, flower food will increase their life. Though flowers have enjoyed sunbathing before their being cut, once they are clipped, keeping them cool is vital.
    • Bleach, when mixed in very small amounts into buckets or vases of water, will resist the growth of bacteria and work to maintain freshness in flowers.
